message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of blurring of vision and distortion in the center when looking at an Amsler grid, along with the fundoscopic image showing drusen and pigmentary changes, suggest the most likely diagnosis is age-related macular degeneration. Hypertensive and diabetic retinopathy typically present with hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton-wool spots. Cystoid macular edema presents with a cystic lesion on fundoscopy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including difficulty reading, blurred vision, and seeing wavy lines on an Amsler grid, suggest Age-related macular degeneration. The image of the retina shown in the question also supports this diagnosis. Hypertensive retinopathy and Diabetic retinopathy may cause visual changes, but the symptoms and fundoscopic findings are different from those seen in Age-related macular degeneration. Cystoid macular edema may be associated with Diabetes, but the Amsler Grid would not show wavy lines in this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms of central blurring of vision, distortion of central vision on an Amsler grid, and preference for holding reading material above or below eye level all suggest age-related macular degeneration. The image of the retina also shows characteristic findings of drusen deposits and pigment changes. The patient's history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus may increase her risk for this condition, but they do not suggest an alternative diagnosis of hypertensive or diabetic retinopathy or cystoid macular edema.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of blurring of vision and difficulty reading, along with the appearance of the retina through fundoscopy and the presence of wavy lines on the Amsler grid, suggest age-related macular degeneration. Hypertensive retinopathy and diabetic retinopathy typically have different visual symptoms and fundoscopic appearances. Cystoid macular edema may also cause blurring of vision, but typically presents differently on fundoscopy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of difficulty reading, blurring of vision, and need for a bright light, all of which are common in age-related macular degeneration. The Amsler grid also shows wavy and bent lines in the center, which is typical for this condition. The image of the retina shows drusen, which are also commonly seen with age-related macular degeneration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of increasing blurring of vision in both eyes, difficulty reading, and distorted lines on the Amsler grid suggest age-related macular degeneration. This is further supported by the appearance of the retina on fundoscopy, which shows drusen deposits and pigment changes. Hypertensive and diabetic retinopathy and cystoid macular edema may also cause vision changes, but they typically have different presentations on fundoscopy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described by the patient, including blurring of vision, difficulty with reading, requiring bright light, and distorted lines on the Amsler grid, are consistent with age-related macular degeneration. The image shown in the fundoscopy also supports this diagnosis, as it shows drusen deposits in the macula, which are characteristic of age-related macular degeneration. The patient's hypertension and diabetes may contribute to the development and progression of the disease, but they are not the primary cause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of blurring vision, difficulty reading, and distortion of Amsler grid lines suggest age-related macular degeneration. The image of her retina shows a characteristic finding of a large drusen, which is a hallmark feature of age-related macular degeneration. Hypertensive and diabetic retinopathy typically present with different symptoms and fundoscopic findings such as cotton wool spots, exudates, and hemorrhages. Cystoid macular edema may also present with blurring of vision, but the Amsler grid would not show distortion of lines.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of increasing blurring of vision, difficulty reading, and the appearance of the lines in the center of the Amsler grid being wavy and bent, along with the image of the retina shown, strongly suggest age-related macular degeneration. Hypertensive retinopathy and diabetic retinopathy would have distinct features visible on fundoscopy, and cystoid macular edema typically presents with distorted vision and decreased color vision.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of blurring vision, difficulty reading, and using a bright light to see, along with the wavy and bent lines on an Amsler grid, suggest age-related macular degeneration. The image of the retina also shows drusen, which are common in this condition. Hypertensive and diabetic retinopathy usually present with hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton wool spots. Cystoid macular edema presents with macular edema and decreased vision.
